subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Quikscript extensions to Shavian (or separate script)

messageBody:
On Apr 20, 2013, at 12:48 AM, Michael Everson <everson@...> wrote:

> On 20 Apr 2013, at 05:08, Nathan Sharfi <bonusfrogs@...> wrote:
>
>> On Apr 19, 2013, at 5:20 PM, Jean-François Colson <jf@...> wrote:
>>
>>> For T (sorry, I forgot the keyword) which can be written either downwards or upwards, the half form can be linked to a following letter or, sometimes, to the previous one, as in the word “out”. In some cases, there might be ambiguity for the rendering engine and the writer could want to specify with which letter (the previous one or the next one) half T should be linked. Therefore, a ZWJ or a ZWNJ could be useful.
>>
>> I'm not sure this needs to be something the UTC and friends bothers with. That said, ZWJ and ZWNJ could be useful, even if the only people who need to pay attention them are those who make keyboard layouts. For example, if I wanted to type "arrears" and spell it UTTER ROE EAT ROE ZOO, I'd be annoyed if UTTER ROE were smashed together in a ligature across a syllable boundary.
>
> Shavian, in having explicitly-encoded -r characters, solves that problem. If QS and Shavian were unified, wouldn't you be better off using those -r characters?
>
> Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com/

If you have explicitly-encoded -r characters:
- your keyboard layout will need to have keys for each -r character
- OWE ROW (used by Californians, at least) will be an (the?) one R-controlled vowel sound that doesn't have a key of its own
- UTTER [syllable break] ROE does the right thing without having to type exotic invisible characters
- you won't need a dedicated key for an exotic invisible character

If you expect your fonts to compose your -r characters:
- you'll need a ZWNJ key if you cannot guarantee that the entire text production and viewing chain will be able to automatically detect syllable breaks (something about as difficult to implement as `hyphens: auto`— something that will be a loooooooong time in coming)
- you won't need to assign keys to precomposed -r characters, saving space for angle parentheses and whatever code point the namer dot should be
- you won't need to remember that R-controlled vowels have a special key for them — an irritation comparable to only being able to input bat’chim with the precomposed combinations on sebeolsik final

Considering how often I write R-controlled vowels and how infrequently I'd need to explicitly break [vowel] [syllable break] ROE, expecting my fonts to handle that sort of thing sounds like the least irritating option most of the time. In the age of OpenType fonts, putting precomposed -r code points in documents seems as silly as sticking in LATIN SMALL LIGATURE FFL.
